[7] discuss different algorithms to compute troposphere delays by ray tracing through numerical weather models, including the exact solution of the Eikonal equation (e.g., [8]).

[7] have shown that other algorithms, named “Thayer approximation” and “Piecewise linear approximation”(PWLA), can give nearly identical results as the Eikonal solution, differing by less than a millimeter even for very low elevation angles.

The PWLA, as discussed in [7], has the advantage that Snell's law of refraction can be applied for a horizontally stratified media, under the assumption that refractivity is decreasing exponentially with height.

Given that numerical weather models are preprocessed as described by [7], one can upload these data sets into GPU memory either as one large shared memory block or as separate 3-D textures which have to be accessed via a dedicated function which relates between the desired epoch and the corresponding texture.

Since textures on the GPU provide the bilinear interpolation, which is also required for the PWLA (see also [7]) when computing the refractivities at the points \$n_{a, k + 1}\$ and \$n_{b, k + 1}\$, one could expect that this approach is faster than the usage of standard shared memory.
The Kashima Ray-tracing Tools [7] were compiled with the GNU C++ compiler, utilizing only one of the four CPU cores.
